title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines "article of fur" and "interstate or foreign commerce" and clarifies the term "import" in relation to fur products. The Act defines key terms such as "import," "person," and "Secretary" in relation to fur products and regulations. It also specifies the definition of a "steel jaw leghold trap" as a spring-powered device used in trapping. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" is defined as a spring-powered device with two steel jaws designed to capture an animal by snapping closed on its limb. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. No fur article can be traded if it comes from an animal trapped in a steel jaw leghold trap. It is illegal to import, export, or possess such fur, transport leghold traps, or violate regulations set by the Secretary. Penalties apply for knowingly breaking these rules. Any person who knowingly violates regulations set by the Secretary regarding fur trade from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps may face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and two years imprisonment for subsequent violations. The Secretary will reward individuals with half of the fine paid for providing information leading to a conviction of a criminal violation under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement of the Act is outlined in Section 5. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, and seize packages and make arrests without a warrant for violations. The Secretary enforces the Act by detaining, searching, and seizing packages, making arrests without a warrant, and executing warrants issued by judges or magistrates. Seized items are held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. Seized items are held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. The Secretary may allow the owner to post a bond instead of holding the item. Any fur or steel jaw leghold trap in violation of the Act is subject to forfeiture. The Attorney General can seek to enjoin violators of the Act or its regulations. The Secretary will create necessary regulations to enforce the Act, and the Act will become effective one year after its enactment.
